comments.commentBody: "Those in government have a responsibility to all who live in our country, not loyalty to lobbyists or special interest groups."  Ah, were it only so!  You have described what should be, rather than what actually is.  In reality, they are heavily beholden to the special interests that financed their last campaigns.  Perhaps you think that they will now be returning to Washington to roll up their sleeves and tackle the country's many problems?  Dream on.  They will be spending most of their time fundraising for their next campaigns by ingratiating themselves with deep-pocketed special interests.  Will they put the interests of the country above those of their financiers or the partisan demands of their party?  Impossible, because that would be political suicide.  Nice system we have here, isn't it?

It is heartening to hear President Obama speak of addressing 'climate change', which is considered a reality and a threat by the vast majority of reputable climatologists world wide. Recently in the Times, I read the perspectives of teenagers who will in just a few years have the vote. They are rightly concerned about what we as the adults in this world do now, as this will greatly affect them and future generations.

Something which is looming over our nation is the huge and growing federal deficit. The U.S. now spends over 4 times what China does on military and defense and 10 times what Russia spends. To the President's credit, the Iraq War which Bush initiated has been dealt with in a sensible way, with our troops leaving. And plans are in place to vacate Afghanistan by 2014.

Those in government have a responsibility to all who live in our country, not loyalty to lobbyists or special interest groups. Most Americans diligently work hard at their respective professions. Our President, members of Congress and the Supreme Court have a deep responsibility, to look forward and to prepare us as a nation for what the future holds. Those in government are elected as professionals, to safeguard our interests. It is my hope that going forward, they will behave as professionals, elevating themselves above the petty squabbles so commonly seen in recent years.

You want them to pretend to have common sense in order to get elected. You are concerned with what they should do and pretend to be in order to win, not with what they should be in order to govern wisely.

You could be dismayed if your friend found incorrectly given her situation that safety nets were vital, but if her own understanding of her position was accurate then they were vital for her and your dismay is unreasonable and unwarranted. Your dismay should be that in a rich country she must worry about safety nets; in every other country as rich as ours she would be able to take the safety net for granted and worry instead about how to get back out of it, a much more productive worry and one that a tea party type would be proud to have.

They are so busy worrying about getting out the far right base that they forget they could have independents and even moderate Democrats if they showed even a modicum of common sense. Mitt Romney's "me, too's" on many Obama positions during the debates were too little too late.

And it is not just demographics. I was dismayed when a former tea party friend voted straight party Democratic. She found that safety nets and the health care bill were vital.

Well the GOP agenda since Obama's re-election was to deny him a second term. Now that Obama's been re-elected, the question is whether Republican legislators still feel that working with Democrats is detrimental to their individual interests or will they continue to follow a collectivist party line. Collectivist in the sense that individual congressmen choose not to work with Democrats because their PARTY has adopted a unified position that is contrary to the interests of the opposing party.

Although I'm a liberal, I held the belief that should Romney have won the election, Washington would have been more functional, and Romney would have been a liberal president. Meaning that GOP congressmen would have worked with a liberal president to promote a liberal agenda, fiscal stimulus, expansionary government, higher taxes on the rich, only because the executive was a member of the same party. I'm not suggesting that ideology is irrelevant to Republicans. But we all realize that there is a historic pattern, in which Republican congressmen will forget their positions of austerity and small government when a fellow Republican occupies the executive. A large part of this may be financial interests which promote our political campaigns, but there is also a psychological element. An inherent partisanship that can only be resolved through self-analysis.

That, of course, depends entirely on the Democratic majority remembering to show up for the 2014 elections, rather than thinking that these minor non-presidential elections are about nothing more than choosing aldermen and dogcatchers, or bellyaching about all the miracles Obama hasn't been able to work since he got reelected.

Let us here highly resolve NEVER to let 2010 happen again. The evil legacy of 2010 lives on in every congressional district gerrymandered to ensure a Republican majority, in every potential job in infrastructure reconstruction unprovided, in every federal judgship and significant executive office left unfilled, iand in every day of no response to global environmental degradation and climate change.

Liberals have to learn from the right wingers how electoral setbacks and being in the political minority have to be countered by building organizations, building causes, and building sustained enthusiasm--only for a good cause, not for reactionary and regressive ones.
*election not re-election

I think Nate's blog is the strongest argument for the basic education of statistics being a vital part of secondary school education- nay, even a vital part of primary school education. In the WWII age where relativity and nuclear physics seemed so vital, so sexy, we locked into geometry and calculus as the epitome of basic higher mathematical education. I don't disparage that at all, but so much of today's complexity (another mathematical concept) boils down to a basic understanding of statistics - whether interpreting political trends, economics, clinical studies, climatology, genetics, DNA analysis, ecology, lotteries, and so forth for an endlessly driven data society - we can't begin to make sense, or let alone make sensible decisions, without a basic understanding of statistics.
I doubt "Project Orca" will be a wake-up call to the extreme right to embrace or to promote an fundamental understanding of statistics by our citizenry, but as a chemist by training and a physician by practice, I cannot see how we will make it out of a 19th century frame of reference into a 21st century world without a fundamental and universal understanding of statistics.

The way the story is told, the visuals, even the tunes in the soundtrack resemble the dark knight series, and there aren't too much action scenes, which did not bother me as an audience. What bothered me is the lack of originality and the lack of tension.
The first twenty minutes of the film was exciting, attention grabbing, and had non stop action, but after that, everything seemed to be resolved easily after a couple of kicks and fists, and the action scenes looked very familiar as if we have seen them before for hundred times. "The Silence of the Lambs (1991)", did not contain a lot of action scenes but there was always tension and originality.

All the things said about McClellan, except possibly his success in business, could be said about Lee (he also was second in his class at West Point and served with bravery in Mexico.  He was successful in a form of business in his management of his wife's estate).  Which raises the question why didn't Lee have the same apparent fear of failure as McClellan?

I don't think it was a question of disloyalty or politically-motivated foot-dragging. James McPherson has an interesting speculation on McClellan's psychology. Up until taking command of what he would turn into the Army of the Potomac, his life had been a series of successes. He was second in his class, brevetted for bravery under fire in Mexico and after a successful military career, also did well in business.

Once in command of an army that would have to take the field, he now faced the possibility of failure, failure that could cost needless lives and maybe even lose a war. Although he had demonstrated physical courage, he seemed to have lacked the moral courage to take the big risks. Thus, there were always excuses not to advance involving the enemy somehow outnumbering him or his horses being fatigued.

Good and persuasive column, but for the premise that Barack Obama
is center-left. He is not-- if anything the President is himself center-right, as that term has been traditionally been defined. (Many of Richard Nixon's domestic policy positions were to the left of Obama's, and Obama's views on the social safety net are consistent with many of Ronald Reagan's stands.)

As this suggests, the two major parties have both moved steadily to the right since Reagan assumed office. While this is especially true of Republicans, it has also become notoriously difficult to identify liberal Democrats in recent years, with the exception of Barney Frank and Dennis Kucinich, both of whom are leaving office this year. Perhaps Elizabeth Warren will bring a liberal perspective to Capitol Hill in 2013. But Barack Obama is by no stretch of the imagination center-left.

Aside from hoping that you run for President in 2016, I just wanted to note that I'm an older working class white guy, with an Obama sticker on his forklift, and I'm a socialist, like any other acceptably rational person of my description would normally be in any actually "developed" country, and so far as I know, no one in my immediate family has ever voted Republican; yet we respected all sorts of Republicans as we knew them when I was young.

For example, Earl Warren, who would be tarred and feathered by the modern evil twin that his party has become were he still alive to endure this; or how about Dwight Eisenhower? His astonishing warning of the power of the military-industrial complex, by the single person on earth who no doubt knew more about this than any other?

No one, anywhere, expects anything close to this standard of genuine ethics from Republicans now; we expect pandering to a so-aptly named "base", and to the absurdly self-serving hypocrisy of those who profit to prod and enrage that base, certainly to the detriment of the country, and to the regret of even socialists such as myself.

Regret, because it would be genuinely interesting to know what an Eisenhower or Warren would have to say about where we are, and where we're going from here; as opposed to the "thought" we get from the Hannitys and Limbaughs of the current conservative world, which would be flattered to be called merely junk.

Who does that leave worthy of respect? David Brooks, but who else?

During the summer, as all those predictions were being thrown around about the "nail-biter" and "toss-up" that this election would likely be, I regularly turned to Nate's column to look at those swaths of blue on the map -- thinking all the time, "But he keeps saying that it's not that close in the Electoral College." It provided me with comfort as President Obama held onto this lead through those days -- nudging a little closer at times, then nudging back, but always staying around 75-80%+ percentages most of the time.

And in those dark, dark days of early October, as the red and blue lines on Nate's two graphs precipitously converged, I continued to come here not only to reassure myself about all the blue states that didn't seem to budge, but also for his state-by-state commentary, and his assessments that, even with his post-first debate gains, Gov. Romney still hadn't gotten closer than 60-40 odds. It wasn't that I felt that Nate was a partisan hack -- far from it, for as in 2008, I was always reassured that he was just reporting what the statistics and what the polling showed, whether good or bad for either side.

So thank you, Nate -- you were a refreshing oasis of sanity amid all the efforts to spin the latest news cycle into "momentum" or "toss-up" status. As much as I was pleased by the results last night, though -- I was even more delighted to see your calm, careful work vindicated as each state turned the same color as they had been on your pre-election maps.
